An Islamic extremist accused of destroying religious monuments in the ancient city of Timbuktu will be tried for war crimes in a groundbreaking case at the international criminal court this week.

Ahmad al-Mahdi, a former junior civil servant in Mali’s department of education, joins the ranks of the world’s most notorious dictators and warlords in being tried by the ICC. His alleged crimes, however, are not those usually dealt with by The Hague’s prosecutors: the destruction of small mausoleums made from mud in the middle of the desert.

Related: Timbuktu mayor: Mali rebels torched library of historic manuscripts

Mahdi’s lawyer has said his client will plead guilty to directing the destruction of nine mausoleums and a mosque when the trial starts on Monday; it would be the first time an ICC defendant accused of war crimes has entered a guilty plea.

Mahdi’s trial is the ICC’s first for destroying cultural heritage, something that its chief prosecutor, Fatou Bensouda, has called “a callous assault on the dignity and identity of entire populations, and their religious and historical roots”.

Timbuktu is slowly turning to dust, but was once known as the city of gold for its great wealth. Despite being a byword for the end of the earth, the city was a centre of learning, knowledge and culture on par with Florence during the Italian renaissance. Its university had 25,000 students, more than Timbuktu’s estimated current population of less than 15,000, and its libraries held hundreds of thousands of precious manuscripts from the 12th-16th centuries.

In 2012, Tuareg rebels attacked Timbuktu, backed by al-Qaida in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) and armed with weapons from Libya. They enforced sharia law, banning music – the lifeblood of Malian culture – forcing women to wear the burqa and preventing girls from attending school.

Mahdi, who is from a village 62 miles (100km) outside Timbuktu, is accused of having joined the jihadis, who were trying to hire locals to build their credibility, and leading the vice squad.

He was no stranger to Timbuktu. Mahdi met his wife, got married and trained as a teacher in the city. According to magazine Jeune Afrique, a former colleague remembers him as quiet and polite, but that, as a Wahhabi, he refused to look into her eyes or shake hands with any woman.

His alleged orders were to attack the shrines of Sufi saints, break down a mosque door that locals believed had to stay shut until the end of the world, and burn priceless manuscripts from Timbuktu’s archive.

Mohamed Aouini, Mahdi’s defence lawyer, said his client would plead guilty to the crimes. “He wants to be truthful to himself and he wants to admit the acts that he has committed. And he wants to ask at the same time for pardon from the people of Timbuktu and the Malian people,” Aouini told an earlier hearing at the ICC. “He regrets all the actions that he has committed.”

Thanks to Abdel Kader Haidara, a collector and librarian, 95% of the city’s 400,000 manuscripts were secretly smuggled to Bamako, the Malian capital, by boat and car. They are now being painstakingly restored, catalogued and digitalised. Of what was left in Timbuktu, about 4,000 were lost, stolen or burned by the jihadis before they fled in 2013 when French and Malian troops advanced on the city.

A peace agreement was signed in Mali last year, but fighting has continued, particularly in the lawless north, where jihadis and bandits thrive. The UN mission there is the deadliest in the world.

Haidara had spent a decade travelling the region by camel and canoe, buying manuscripts from families: his story is documented in a book by Joshua Hammer. He took a particular interest in manuscripts that showed Islam not as a religion of intolerance, but of humanity and moderation.

Related: Destruction of Timbuktu manuscripts is an offence against the whole of Africa | Jonathan Jones

This was a key part of Timbuktu’s “extraordinary civilisation”, according to Cynthia Schneider, a scholar of relations with the Islamic world and a former US ambassador.

“The great characteristic of Timbuktu, which is why it’s so important today, was tolerance, plurality and diversity,” she said. “It was a centre of learning, but also, importantly, a centre of inquiry.

“The manuscripts include discussions of human rights, women’s rights, children’s rights, good governance, good business practices. And there’s a whole lot of scientific ones, philosophy, literature, music. All of these characteristics that we tend to associate with Western civilisation – all of that was going on in Timbuktu.”

Schneider co-directs Timbuktu Renaissance, a project that aims to foster peace, unity and economic redevelopment in the city, where the economy has crumbled since its main income, tourism, abruptly dried up in 2012.

The tombs of the Sufi saints, who are thought to protect the city against evil spirits, were rebuilt with the help of Unesco.

In a country where people have, in the recent past, been summarily executed, raped and had their hands amputated, some question the significance of what some Malians call the “trial of stones and earth”. However, the destruction of shrines and monuments has become a hallmark of Islamic extremism, with many statues, mosques, churches and tombs being attacked in Iraq and Afghanistan.

Irina Bokova, the director general of Unesco, said attacks such as these were “a mark of a genocidal project” as they amounted to the attempted annihilation of the other. “I hope that the trial will have a tremendous deterrent effect – a deterrent to Isis and others,” Schneider said, adding that it was important for the people of Timbuktu that Mahdi had admitted to his crimes.

Although not particularly architecturally beautiful, the small mud shrines are key to the identity of Timbuktu, Schneider said, recalling what the city’s imam told her after the attacks. “When they destroyed our tombs, they destroyed our souls,” he said.

As we celebrate the ambition, calibre, and achievements of champions competing at the Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro, there is also the stark reality that malnutrition is compromising the survival, health and potential of billions of individuals globally.

Malnutrition is often confused with hunger, but they are quite different. Hunger, which affects around 800 million people, is the physical experience of a lack of food. Malnutrition on the other hand, results from the consumption and absorption of either too little of the right kinds of food or too much of the wrong kind.

Globally, one in three people suffer from malnutrition and according to the World Health Organisation over 3 million children die from it every year. Malnutrition is also a crucial factor determining whether a woman will survive her pregnancy, whether her child will reach his or her fifth birthday, whether they go to school and learn, get a job and contribute to society.

For decades malnutrition has been undermining the growth, development and economic potential of billions. Leading experts (pdf) have estimated the annual economic losses on account of global malnutrition at $3.5tn (£2.7tn) and there is ample evidence that tackling malnutrition offers some of the highest economic returns.

Related: We must focus on the UN goals that are the best value for money

Despite this, the level of political commitment to this issue is shocking. Global donors and governments spend just over 1% of their aid and national budgets in efforts to tackle malnutrition (pdf) – a fraction of what is needed.

Who can better understand the importance of good nutrition than an Olympic athlete? The landmark 2013 Nutrition for Growth summit, co-hosted by the UK government and the government of Brazil, following the London Olympics in 2012, was a much needed catalyst to get world leaders, businesses, philanthropies, and civil society to talk about malnutrition. At the end of the event, the baton was passed to Brazil to host a follow up summit ahead of the Olympics in Rio to check in on progress and commit new resources to accelerate success.

The much-awaited Brazilian Nutrition for Growth event took place in Rio on 4 August, a day before the opening ceremony. However, what materialised fell short of all expectations. Despite powerful addresses from Brazilian and Kenyan Olympians Robson Caetano da Silva and Tegla Loroupe, who spoke passionately about the need to improve nutrition globally, the most critical part of the summit was missing – political and financial commitments. Unlike the London summit, which was David Cameron’s brainchild, heads of state from donor and developing countries were conspicuous by their absence in Rio, including high-level representation from the UK.

Related: A girl's view of the 17 sustainable development goals - in pictures

This was not surprising given the recent political turmoil in Brazil, as well as the change in leadership in the UK, but disappointing nonetheless. With every global summit, there is always a chance that unforeseen external events may dilute its scale and outcome, but we mustn’t let that take us off track. Efforts to reduce malnutrition cannot be scaled up without political leaders stepping up and putting their money where their mouths are.

At the end of last year, we as a global community adopted the sustainable development goals, which enshrines a target to end all forms of malnutrition by 2030. The Copenhagen Consensus thinktank of economists recently recommended prioritising this target for high social returns on investments.

We know what is needed to achieve this ambitious goal. The World Bank and partners estimate that an additional annual investment of $7bn (£5.3bn) is required over the next ten years to achieve international targets on reducing stunting, wasting, and anaemia, and increasing rates of breastfeeding. Current global spending levels fall short of this at around only $4bn (£3bn) a year.

Related: We won't conquer the mountains of the SDGs without humility

But there is still hope. At the G7 in Germany in 2015, heads of state committed to lift 500 million people out of hunger and malnutrition. Following the G7’s continued commitment to the Nutrition for Growth process at this year’s meeting, the 2017 G7 summit in Italy represents the next opportunity for donor governments and developing countries to commit new resources to tackle malnutrition and finish what they agreed to accomplish three years ago in London.

As the Olympics come to a close, it is clear that the millions of malnourished children, mothers and young people can’t wait until Tokyo 2020 for another global pledging moment for nutrition. There is too much at stake.

To most of the world, the place where James Foley spent his childhood must look about as good as it gets: a clapboard house with a large garden in a small town next to a beautiful lake. Visualise the American dream and this is it, pretty much. Wolfeboro, New Hampshire, where Foley grew up in a close-knit family of five siblings, is an affluent corner of a well-off state in the world’s most advanced industrial economy. The worst thing you can say about the place is that it’s where Mitt Romney goes on holiday.

This was where James Foley started his life. And on 19 August 2014, the world found out where and how it ended via a video posted on YouTube entitled “A Message to America”. Foley, a 40-year-old freelance photojournalist who had been kidnapped in Syria two years earlier, was dressed in an orange jumpsuit and kneeling on the ground. With his hands tied behind his back, he recited what was obviously a prepared script that listed America’s crimes. And then, we all know what happened next: a masked man with a distinctive British accent put a knife to his throat and decapitated him.

I saw his image being used as propaganda, for political agendas, and for me as a friend, that was uncomfortable

At home in New Hampshire, Diane Foley, his mother, found out when she got a call from a journalist she didn’t know who asked her for her “reaction”.

If you wanted to eviscerate the American dream, to disembowel it, and string it up from a lamp-post for all the world to see how vulnerable it really is, how easily vanquished, then murdering James Wright Foley on the internet in front of a global audience is not a bad place to start.

Foley could have been the poster boy for the all-American way of life: a handsome, square-jawed idealist from a well-off family – his father, John, a doctor, his mother a pillar of the local Catholic church – who’d had all the advantages that western life can confer: a loving environment, a good education, a childhood unmarked by war or famine or disaster. That he had elected to leave all that and go and cover the ongoing insurgency in Syria for a few hundred dollars a pop from whichever outlet he could get to take his footage was neither here nor there to his captors.

His murder was the first of a series of videos of western hostages being executed and it presaged an new form of terror. It was the video that introduced the world to “Jihadi John”, or Mohammed Emwazi as we now know he was called. We know quite a lot about him now – how he grew up in upmarket parts of London – Maida Vale and St John’s Wood, how Foley’s fellow prisoners named him and two fellow British jihadis “the Beatles”, and how, in November 2015, he was killed by a US drone strike. But his victims have remained pale and shadowy in comparison. They’ve been stranded, for ever, in orange jumpsuits, destined to end their days reading someone else’s words.

And this is what Jim: The James Foley Story, a new documentary about the life and last days of James Foley, seeks to rectify. It’s an intimate, moving portrait – nominated this month for an Emmy – made through interviews with his family, friends and fellow hostages, though it’s not until the very end of the film, when his brother, Michael, addresses the nameless person behind the camera, that you realise just how intimate it is.

“You know him as well as I do,” Michael Foley says to the camera, talking about the video of his brother’s death. “He would never have done those things if there wasn’t someone else who would be harmed. He never cared for himself.” Because the film-maker, Brian Oakes, did know him well, had known him, in fact, since he was seven years old, and grew up with him in the same small town of Wolfeboro. And the impetus for the film, he tells me from his home in New York, came from the desire to rescue his friend Jim, the boy he’d grown up with, from the media creation and propaganda tool that he’d become.

“That was the original catalyst for me wanting to make this film – that image of Jim, of his death, his execution, which was seen throughout the world. I saw this image being used for a lot of different purposes. It was used as propaganda. It was used in politics, for political agendas and for me… as a friend and someone who knew him, that was really… made me uncomfortable. I just wanted to take on the responsibility to tell Jim’s story.”

And he does. People have a habit of saying nice things about the dead but it’s clear that Foley was a particularly special case. When I speak to Diane Foley on the phone at her home in New Hampshire, she calls the film “a gift”. She’s known Oakes pretty much all his life, but hadn’t wanted the family to take part initially. “It was very soon after Jim’s death that he came and asked us and I was truly not ready for it. I loved Brian. He was a childhood best friend but I was reluctant, initially. It was his siblings who wanted to do it. They knew Brian best and they wanted people to know who Jim really was and why he put his life on the line.”

It’s all there, his life from childhood on, warts and all. His idealism and easy manner comes across but also a certain waywardness, a lack of desire to be pinned down by convention or loan repayment plans. But it’s the interviews with his fellow hostages that are at the heart of the film. For two years, when his family didn’t know whether he was alive or dead, he was sharing a tiny cell with a changing roster of other western hostages, not all of whom were murdered by Isis.

“Those interviews were the most intense of the entire film-making process,” says Oakes. “Here were men who were with Jim over the course of months, sometimes years, when we didn’t know where he was. We didn’t know if Jim was alive or dead or where he was, who had him. This was a huge black hole and for me to be able to sit down and talk to those who were with him and to unravel that mystery was very cathartic.

“Michael and Katie, James’s siblings came too and it was very emotional and difficult but also quite amazing.”

One of the former hostages he talked to was Nicolas Hénin, a French freelance journalist who had spent a long time in the Middle East and who recounts how much he disliked, initially, James’s habit of calling everyone “bro”.

“I just do not use this kind of working-class colloquial language,” Hénin tells me over the phone from France. “It’s just not my style. I’m like, ‘I am not your brother!’” But Foley did become like a brother to him. “We invented a life during these months in captivity,” he says in the film. “And when you invent a life, you have to invent also a family.”

Everyone, at some stage, fell out with everyone else, he tells me. “There were sometimes a few dozen people in a tiny room. In such circumstances, it’s normal that every single one of us struggled with every single other. Apart from Jim. He had these incredible social skills. It really stands out. He was the only one who didn’t have any big dispute with anyone else.”

Hénin and Foley became close, not least because for one 10-day period, they were handcuffed to each another. And it was shattering to Hénin when he, like everyone else, learned via the internet of his friend’s death. “My first reaction when I watched this film [the Islamic State video] was horror, but my second reaction was pride. I was just proud of my friend. I was truly impressed by his behaviour where so many others would just scream like babies. Even though I had been through a lot of things in common with him, I’m not at all sure I would have found the courage to behave like that. His comportment, his language… he speaks strongly, he looks straight, he stands straight. He just acts like a man. His condition was like an animal but Jim was a man. And somehow, he just behaved as a free man.

“I shared his fate for months. We were comrades, for 10 months we shared everything except our passports. And that’s what saved my life. And took his.”

We invented a life during those months in captivity. And when you invent a life, you have to invent also a family

Because the fact that Nicolas Hénin is around to tell the tale is due to his nationality. The French and other Europeans negotiated to get their hostages free. The British and Americans did not. John Cantlie, a British journalist who was captured with Foley, is still being held. And Foley and his fellow Americans and Brits are all dead. It’s still a bitter pill for the Foleys to swallow.

“It’s just terrible,” says Diane Foley. “I was appalled at the way we were treated. I just couldn’t believe it. We just felt so alone. For nearly two years, we didn’t know if Jim was alive, and we had very few people who were with us on it.” As a family, they were told by the government that the best chance of securing their son’s release was to maintain a news blackout, a stipulation they eventually broke, and that they now feel didn’t help.

“We had no idea how to find James and how to get him home once he was found. We just went to everyone we could, begging for help. But at that time, there was nothing in place. I was appalled to find that there was nobody in our own government whose mission it was to help us. It’s not like in Britain or France, which have a structure in place. People were sympathetic. They listened. I think individually they cared but it was just at the bottom of their list.

“It was just appalling to us. It was really up to private individuals who were the most helpful to me – like David Bradley, the publisher of the Atlantic and Phil Balboni, [for whom Foley was working] of the GlobalPost in Boston.”

It was also, Nicolas Hénin, believes, a terrible miscalculation. He has gone on to write a book about the causes of the insurgency in Syria and Iraq – Jihad Academy: the rise of the Islamic State – and believes that the Americans underestimated the crisis from the beginning. “They thought we had been taken by dangerous amateurs. They didn’t realise what was at stake. I don’t actually know what was exchanged for myself, if it was money or something else. But even if a ransom had been paid for Jim, it would have been worth it, beyond any moral consideration. It would have been worth it from a security perspective because the propaganda impact was so very high.”

It was. The film does not contain footage from the video and states that fact, explicitly, at the start. “I didn’t include it for a number of reasons but one was because I believe that people have a choice whether to watch it or not,” Brian Oakes tells me. He himself hadn’t watched it until he came to make the film. “And in fact, I still haven’t to this day, not the unedited version. It was not something I choose to do. I don’t want to see that kind of war pornography. To me, that video is just a piece of propaganda, a recruitment tool.”

That image – of Foley in an orange jumpsuit on his knees in the Syrian desert – marked a new chapter in the use of terror; it became a symbol of the strength and ingenuity of Isis and evidence of the weakness of the west in confronting a whole new type of enemy. Clare Morgana Gillis, fellow freelance journalist and friend of Foley’s, states in the film that 94% of Americans are aware of Foley’s death, making it the news event with the second highest recognition after 9/11. Nobody would have hated that more than him, she says. He went to Syria to try and tell the world about the atrocities that were going on there. “And that was the takeaway?” she asks. The death of a single American reaped more publicity than any other report on the country, ever.

It was another freelance, Nicole Tung, who rang Diane Foley at home in New Hampshire when, in November 2012, Foley and John Cantlie failed to show up at an arranged meeting place at the Turkish border. Later, the family discovered that the two men had been spotted when they broke their journey to file their copy from an internet cafe; shortly afterwards, armed gunmen forced their car to stop just a few miles from the border.

“I was just incredulous that it had happened, to be honest,” says Diane Foley. “I just couldn’t believe it. That’s how much denial I was in. I was so ill prepared.”

Denial because this wasn’t the first time that James Foley had been kidnapped. He’d hopped around in his 20s and early 30s, studying creative writing, becoming a teacher in an inner-city school in Arizona, and then he seemed to find the thing he’d been looking for: journalism. “Something seemed to click,” says Diane. It gave him a purpose, a mission. And when the revolution kicked off in Libya, he went.

Libya was where Morgana Gillis met Foley for the first time, and the main attraction for them both was that it was exciting and it was cheap. “It was a Mad Max type war,” said Foley when he returned in 2011. Photojournalist Nicole Tung, another friend of Foley’s interviewed in the film, says, “Many of us aren’t old enough to remember journalism in its heyday. What we do is journalism on a shoestring budget.” And with it came a blurring of boundaries. The easiest and cheapest way of getting to the frontline was to hitch a lift with the insurgents.

'I made it too easy for him. I wanted to be supportive. I didn’t say, "Jim, you put us through hell"

Foley was with Morgana Gillis and a South African freelance, Anton Hammerl, when they got caught up in crossfire. Hammerl was shot and killed. Morgana Gillis and Foley were captured. For Diane Foley, it was the darkest time of her life: her son missing, the family not knowing if he was alive or dead. “It was absolutely horrific at the time,” she says. And it’s a measure of everything that the family has been through subsequently that she now adds: “In retrospect, it was nothing.”

After six terrible weeks, they had the Hollywood denouement. He was released, unharmed, and when he returned to his old school of journalism to tell them about his experience, he revealed how much he had learned. “We did a lot of mistakes that day. Conflict zones can be covered safely. But you have to be very experienced. You have to be very, very careful. We didn’t follow a lot of those practices so it’s a tragedy.”

The Q&A session was videoed and Oakes includes a lot of it in his film and, in the light of what happened next, there’s a terrible poignancy to the words that Foley spoke, and yet didn’t seem to hear.

“That’s pure luck that you didn’t get killed there,” he tells the audience. “Pure luck. And you need to either change your behaviour right there or you shouldn’t be doing this. Because it’s not worth your life. It’s not worth seeing your mother, father, brother, and sister bawling. You’re worrying about your grandmother dying because you’re in prison. It’s not worth these things. It’s not worth your life, no matter what romantic ideal you have, no matter what ethic you think you have. It’s never worth that. I’m 37 years old, I should have known that a long time ago.”

Oakes delves into the very human reactions that Foley’s family had when he was kidnapped a second time. His younger brother, John Jr, who has served in the military, is at times bewildered and angry and ultimately, grudgingly respectful of James’s decision to return to a conflict zone. But mostly, angry. “You just wanted to punch him in the face in a loving, brotherly way,” he tells Oakes in the film. His father, John, still shakes his head in disbelief at the memory of it. And Diane tells me that she thinks she “made it too easy for him”.

What do you mean? “I wanted to be supportive. I didn’t say, ‘Well, Jim, you put us through hell.’ I was saying, ‘I respect your decision to do this. And people need to know what is going on in Syria.’ But, to be honest, I put it behind me much too easily. I felt, what are the chances of it happening again? I was really very clueless. Journalists who do this dangerous work need to have those difficult conversations with their families. They need to be prepared and we were not. I was in denial about it. We didn’t have Jim’s will or passwords or bank accounts or emails or things we really needed as a family.”

It’s what she’s trying to do now since James’s death. The family set up the James Foley Foundation and one of their missions has been to try to better prepare freelance journalists for the potential dangers out there. Shortly after James’s death, President Obama called her to offer his condolences. “He thought you were coming to get him,” she told him. A rescue attempt had been made, she found out, but it was too late. The hostages had already been moved to another location. Since then, though, she has worked with the government to get them to create a cross-department “fusion cell”, equipped to deal with another family during another hostage crisis.

The foundation is also lobbying news organisations to take responsibility for the freelances they employ. “We have a responsibility for the people willing to do this work,” she says. “We must protect them. Otherwise, it becomes, as it was at the time Jim was there, very abusive. News organisations are just using these young independent journalists for whatever and giving them nothing back. They did not have their back.”

One of Oakes’s explicit intentions for the film, he says, was to explore the issues around the use of freelance journalists in conflict zones. And what draws them back. Foley, according to Oakes, was “always a kid who loved adventure. He would always take that extra step. When we were teenagers, he was always the one to do something just a little bit more crazy.”

Oakes speculates that Foley was suffering from some sort of post-traumatic stress disorder after his experience in Libya. He took a job in Boston but couldn’t settle. He was lured back by what he calls in the film “the siren song” of the frontline. Though it’s not as straightforward as hero-journalists-tell-world-what-it-needs-to-hear, not least because most of the time the world wasn’t listening. And they were taking huge personal risks to file news stories into a void.

But what Foley wanted – for the world to pay attention to what was happening in Syria – did happen because of his death, I point out to Diane. “Yes. Thanks be to God. But whether Jim knew that, I don’t know.”

I thought interviewing the former hostages would be so bad. Then to find out that the group had created this family…

It isn’t over. That’s what Nicolas Hénin impresses on me when I speak to him. He doesn’t talk about the torture he endured, that Foley endured. They were, variously, beaten, starved, suspended upside down from the ceiling, waterboarded. But that wasn’t what they talked about.

“We were all optimists. It was a decision we all made. Some of us were more realistic but it was harder. You had no control whatsoever over your fate. You are not the one who decides anything. The only thing you can have control of is your morale.” He tells me how during the time he was chained to Foley, he talked late into the night with one of their captors, who was later identified as one of the Brussels bombers.

“He was obsessed with the movie The Matrix. He was telling us: ‘You have left the matrix now. You are living in another matrix. You have left that world. We are creating another world.” It was, he says, a “postmodern experience”.

What do you mean?

“I learned that Syria was just a background. It had nothing to do with Syria. We were western hostages held by western captors.” And it’s not over. John Cantlie is still a prisoner. “I am still careful what I say because they are still holding a friend of mine. The story is not yet over. And normally, when you are a hostage in Nigeria, Afghanistan, you leave the country and you leave it behind. But my captors came back to my home town and they committed crimes here. In November at the Bataclan, they were less than a kilometre from my home.”

His captors, he believes, follow him on Twitter. And the media reporting of every terrorist atrocity further inflames the situation. “You British taught us resilience during the second world war and that is what we need now. That motto – Keep Calm and Carry On – is the one we should adopt here now. The media panic, and the politicians panic and overreact. We should think about what our attackers would love us to do. And then do the opposite.”

Diane Foley and the Foley family have decided to find meaning and purpose in James Foley’s death. For them, it wasn’t a senseless bloodthirsty revenge killing. It has become a mission for them to help others. It proves, Diane tells me, that people aren’t fundamentally bad. They’re the opposite. “People have been so good to us. So many people from all around the world have sent us buckets of mail, donations, prayers. To have good overcome, we need to stand together. That’s why we set up the foundation.”

Related: Sign up to the new-look Media Briefing: bigger, better, brighter

And Brian Oakes makes the same point. “I went into those interviews with the former hostages thinking this is going to be horrible, it’s going to be so bad. Every day was probably torture and beatings. And then to find out that this group of men had created this family and all worked together to survive and had made these games and given each other lectures, it was fascinating.

“And Jim was always like that. He was always this beacon of positivity. And to hear that he was like that even in those super-dark times was amazing. It helps to give him meaning, I hope.”

The film is certainly much less bleak than you’d ever think possible. Oakes says that he deliberately set up the juxtaposition of the idyllic nature of the small town American childhood they shared with the horror that was to follow. “I think those of us who live in a world where everything is peaceful end up taking that for granted. And, that’s why Jim went to Syria, after all.”

Wolfeboro, New Hampshire is not Raqqa, Syria. It is the opposite of Raqqa. But still, even there, it seemed there was some small corner of the Islamic State that was forever Wolfeboro. Daniel Rye Ottosen, a Danish hostage who had also grown close to Foley, tells in the film how for Christmas, sitting in the dark, they gave each other compliments in place of gifts. And his present to Jim? “I told him, ‘You are the most honest person. You are pure good.’ That was our Christmas night. And I really felt that I’d had the best Christmas night in my life.”

Jim: The James Foley Story is in cinemas from 2 September. Preview Q&A screenings with Diane Foley and director Brian Oakes are being held on 31 August and 1 September

Last week, sixth form students across the country celebrated the end of school after receiving their A-level results and on Thursday it will be the turn of GCSE pupils. While many will have plans to go on to further study – university places are at a record high this year – others will be keen to say farewell to exams and head straight out to work.

And it’s a good choice: for school leavers, there’s now more job options than ever before. The biggest graduate recruiters such as EY, Deloitte – and even some top law firms – have opened schemes for school leavers, and there are signs that the pay gap between graduates and non-graduates is shrinking, according to the Institute for Fiscal Studies.

Of course apprenticeships, entry-level jobs and roles with training are also offered across almost all industries – but the first thing to do is work out what type of role you would most enjoy.

If you’re uncertain about the type of industry you want to go into, Denise Taylor, psychologist with Amazing People, says “you should write out a list of your abilities, strengths and interests – and use this to create a career plan”.

Once you’ve decided the industry you want to work in, you then need to find companies that are involved in that area, adds Lis McGuire, founder of Giraffe CVs. “Once you’ve completed your detective work, send in a targeted CV and cover letter that expresses your motivation to work with them.”

But sometimes it can be difficult to know where to start. If you are looking for advice on how to get your first job after finishing school, join us on Wednesday 24 August from 1-2.30pm BST for a live chat with our expert panel. We’ll be discussing:

  • Job options for school leavers.
  • Tips on choosing the right career for you.
  • CV, cover letter and job interview advice.

The Q&A takes place in the comments section below this article. Taking part is easier than ever: create a free Guardian account or log in using your Twitter or Facebook profile to comment. Alternatively, you can tweet us @GuardianCareers or email your questions to charlotte.seager@theguardian.com who can post them for you.

Panel

Emma Finamore is editor at AllAboutSchoolLeavers.co.uk – a website for school and college students, with jobs and information on apprenticeships, school leaver programmes and sponsored degrees. She writes news, features and advice about apprenticeships and puts together careers advice material for schools and colleges.

Hattie Wrixon is co-founder of Unisnotforme.com and an advocate of apprenticeships. Wrixon launched the website Uni’s Not For Me, a resource for young people exploring their career options, when she was 17.

Harriet Jones is a student recruitment advisor at EY. With over four years’ experience within the recruitment sector, she focuses on educating students about the options available to them when they leave school – whether that’s university or an apprenticeship.

Mathieu Pinto Cardoso is the recruitment advisor for law firm Fieldfisher. He is heavily involved in graduate recruitment, diversity initiatives, and manages the whole recruitment process for Fieldfisher legal school leavers programme.

Dan Simmons is head of partnerships at Creative Skillset, an organisation that works with the creative industries to develop skills and talent, supporting productivity and employability. Simmons specialises in creative apprenticeship options for school leavers.

Lynette Daly is the content manager for Walpole Media Group and publisher of Moving On magazine, a publication about careers and qualifications, supported by careers advisers, teachers and parents. She also publishes the Not Going to Uni Apprenticeships Guides, Results Day Guides and HE in FE supplements. Daly worked in education for 15 years before moving into publishing.

Tiana Locker is the youth engagement executive for the City & Guilds Group. She also works as City & Guilds apprentice connect ambassador and is one of their former apprentices. During her apprenticeship, she created a programme to enable apprentices to talk to students about university alternatives.

John has worked in further education for over 20 years supporting employers in the development of Apprenticeships and Graduate programmes in the UK and overseas.

Jon Gregory is a job search, application and interview specialist. He’s the author of Winning That Job, editor of win-that-job.com and has spent many years providing career development advice to students.

The Labour mayor of London, Sadiq Khan, has issued a dramatic call to his party’s members to dump Jeremy Corbyn, saying he has been a disastrous leader who must share a large part of the blame for Britain’s forthcoming exit from the EU.

Related: We cannot win with Jeremy … so I will vote for Owen Smith

Khan, who secured the biggest win by any Labour politician against the Conservative party in more than a decade when he beat Zac Goldsmith to the mayoralty in May, throws his support behind the challenger Owen Smith, arguing that Labour faces all-but-certain defeat at the next general election without a change at the top.

The brutal intervention by Khan in an article for the Observer will give a huge boost to Smith’s camp, and comes as the party prepares to send out ballot papers this week to more than half a million members who are eligible to vote in the leadership contest.

Khan says that while Corbyn – still the clear favourite to win the contest – is a “principled Labour man” whose ideas have brought hope to many, his year in charge has shown he is not up to the job and is “extremely unlikely” to lead the party back to power. Khan’s message is that the party has a duty to oust Corbyn before it is too late.

“Jeremy has already proved that he is unable to organise an effective team and has failed to win the trust and respect of the British people,” Khan writes, adding: “Jeremy’s personal ratings are the worst of any opposition leader on record and the Labour party is suffering badly as a result. He has lost the confidence of more than 80% of Labour’s MPs in parliament – and I am afraid we simply cannot afford to go on like this.”

But it is his comments on what he regards as Corbyn’s abject failure to rally his party behind a pro-EU message before the referendum that will be seen as the most damaging. Khan, in effect, lays much of the blame for Brexit at Corbyn’s door and that of his advisers.

“Throughout the campaign and aftermath, Jeremy failed to show the leadership we desperately needed. His position on EU membership was never clear – and voters didn’t believe him. A third of Labour voters said they did not know where the party stood on the referendum just a week before polling day.

“And you can’t just blame a ‘hostile media’ and let Jeremy and his team off the hook,” he writes. “I know from my own election – up against a nasty and divisive Tory campaign – that if we are strong and clear enough in our convictions, the message will get through to the public. That’s a test that Jeremy totally failed in the EU referendum. Why would things be different in a general election?”

Smith said he was “hugely honoured” to have Khan’s support. “Sadiq ran a fantastic campaign to win power for Labour in London this year, securing a huge mandate from party members and the electorate,” he said.

“He showed that a vision of hope and optimism can win, if it’s backed up with a credible plan to deliver real meaningful change for people’s lives. Since that election we have seen what a difference Labour can make when we hold power.”

Khan’s decision to go on the offensive represents a sudden change in approach by the mayor. Days earlier, in a BBC radio interview, he refused to be drawn on who he would vote for, saying that he preferred to stay out of current internal party arguments, including the debate over who should be leader. But his aides said he had come under growing pressure from supporters and friends in the party to declare his hand and felt it was his duty to make his position known.

Khan lays heavy emphasis on his fear that another four years of Corbyn as leader will ensure another Tory government, leading to more cuts and damage being done to the country’s industrial heartlands.

In an interview with the Observer last weekend, Corbyn blamed any failure to get his messages on policy across on mutinous and disloyal MPs and others who had never accepted his leadership. “We have done our best to get our message out,” he said. “It hasn’t been helped that prominent people in the Labour party – Labour MPs – have spent the last 10 months actively being unsupportive of our policies that have been generally agreed and supported. Now everyone agrees that anti-austerity is the right line to be taking.”

Corbyn said he was using his second campaign for the leadership in 12 months as a dry run for a general election: “Since the resignations in July and the leadership contest, then clearly the public mind has become focused on the leadership contest rather than the future. I’m trying to turn this leadership campaign into a campaign of how we would run a general election. How we would win back those areas of Britain that have become disillusioned – left-behind Britain.”

Related: Jeremy Corbyn's leadership unprofessional and shoddy, says Heidi Alexander

With Corbyn still expected by most MPs to beat Smith and renew his mandate, many senior Labour figures are beginning to focus on how to bring the party together afterwards. Tom Watson, the deputy leader, will back efforts to restore a system of elections to the shadow cabinet, which will be considered by the party’s national executive committee in September as a means to rebuild trust between the leader and MPs.

Explaining his backing for Smith, who is the former shadow work and pensions secretary, Khan says: “On the big issues Owen and I have been on the same side of the argument, including opposing the Iraq war. Owen led and – more importantly – won our fight against the Tories’ unfair cuts to tax credits and disability allowances, which would have hurt the most disadvantaged people in our society.”

He adds: “Simply opposing Tory policies will never be enough to help the people we exist to support. At best, you knock off just the very sharpest edges of the Tory project. Winning elections is how you really make a difference. Only then are you in control – able to shape the agenda and implement Labour policies to create a fairer and more equal society.”

Comments will open on Sunday morning

Stars of the summer

Simone Biles, Usain Bolt, Team GB and this man. Look up “Pride comes before a fall” in any decent Dictionary of Phrase and Fable reprint next year and you’ll find Haitian hurdler Jeffrey Julmis, giving the cameras some classic cool-as-ice posturing before the start of his 110m race – then going head over heels at the first hurdle.

Suit of the summer

IOC head Thomas Bach - surveying Rio’s empty seats, public protests, doping crisis, global criticism and touting scandal involving the arrest of the IOC’s Pat Hickey – and picking out Brazil fans heckling a pole vaulter as being against “the Olympic spirit”. Bach: “This is shocking behaviour… it’s unacceptable at the Olympics.”

Most uplifting cameo

Came on day one – Vanderlei Cordeiro de Lima standing in for Pelé as the official cauldron lighter, 12 years after being robbed of Olympic marathon gold when a drunk, defrocked Irish priest ran on to the course and shoved him into a barrier.

Double-take moment

Also came in the opening ceremony – the event marking the start of a project notorious for violent favela clearances. Helping provide the soundtrack: funk singer Ludmilla, with her Happiness Rap – featuring lyrics: “I just want to be happy in the favela where I was born.”

Best narrative twist

1) Pre-Games, US media warned how their athletes were at risk from Brazil’s crime epidemic; 2) Post-Games, US officials apologised after four US athletes made up a story about Rio gun crime as cover for their night out vandalising a petrol station. A US statement condemned “lapses in judgement and conduct”.

Most overwhelmed

Fiji’s government: dropping a long-standing plan to redesign the national flag, partly because of the patriotic euphoria that followed their first ever medal. PM Voreqe Bainimarama: “I remain convinced that we need to replace these colonial symbols – but just not for the foreseeable future.” Also taking a relaxed view during the public meltdown that followed their rugby sevens gold in week one – Fiji police spokesperson Ana Naisoro: “There is disruption on the roads, congestion, it’s chaos here. But, ah – we’re unconcerned.”

Press release of the summer

Amateur boxing’s governing body Aiba – issuing a robust statement defending its public image after the controversy over judging decisions. “Since the beginning of Rio 2016 Aiba has conducted 250 bouts and remains fully committed to a zero tolerance policy towards fair play in boxing.”

Biggest struggle with irony

Russia’s sports minister, Vitaly Mutko, attacking Rio organisers last week for taking no action over foreign fans booing Russian athletes – accusing officials of failing to uphold Olympic integrity. Mutko said crowds were “not sporting” and must be controlled. “Organisers must protect the competition, and the competitors.”

Story of the summer

Syrian teen Yusra Mardini – winning her heat in the 100m butterfly for the Refugee Team in week one, a year after surviving the capsize of a six-man dinghy carrying 20 refugees towards Lesbos. Mardini spent three hours in the sea helping drag the boat to shore. “I just thought it would be a real shame if I drowned, because I’m a swimmer.” She called the Rio experience “really cool … there are a lot of stories about me now and a lot of people who want to take my picture. This is really good, because it’s helping to spread our message. What everyone in the Refugee Team is saying now is that this does not stop here … This is not the end.”

Best attitude

Body-shamed 5ft 9in, 12.5st Ethiopia swimmer Robel Kiros Habte, reflecting on his mixed press this summer. “They have used dirty language against me and called me fat and a big man and a whale. But Ethiopia is not a swimmers’ country and I have not trained in an Olympic size pool. How could I have won gold? Anyway, now I will lose weight. When I go to Canada for the world championships, I will show them.”

Most remiss

French fencer Enzo Lefort – going into the Games declaring: “I’ve given everything to get here. It’s important not to be distracted” – then being booed by the crowd after his phone fell out of his pocket mid-bout.

Most upbeat

Finnish weightlifter Milko Olavi Tokola – not bothered after images of him fainting head-first off the stage while celebrating went viral. “I know it was on TV, I don’t care! I feel no embarrassment. Hey, I’m an Olympic athlete. I’m just happy.”

Most taken aback

a) Twitter user @joeclarke, reacting to tweets congratulating him on a different Joe Clarke’s K1 canoe slalom gold. “Guys, thank you … but I am currently sitting here ready to start my night shift in Worthing.” And b) the manager of Perrys Motor Sales Ltd in Bolton, @JasonKenny. “I’m an overweight 46yr old. I am NOT at the olympics!”

Quote of the summer

Rio 2016 official spokesperson Mario Andrada – explaining last week why organisers couldn’t be expected to just fix the green water in the pool overnight: “Chemistry is not an exact science.”

Most resilient

Dutch gymnast Yuri van Gelder, expelled from Rio for late night drinking, denying wrongdoing, and going to court to demand “a business class ticket back to Rio”. The judge rejected his case. Dutch media: “Once he was Lord of the Rings. Now he’s Lord of the Drinks.”

Moment of the summer

Nikki Hamblin and Abbey D’Agostino helping each other finish the 5,000m. Hamblin: “When I went down it was like: ‘What’s happening? Why am I on the ground?’. And suddenly there’s this hand on my shoulder, like: ‘Get up, get up, we have to finish this!’ That girl is the Olympic spirit, right there.”

Best death stares

1) Michael Phelps. 2) Boomer Phelps.

Most down to earth

Nineteen-year-old American shooter Ginny Thrasher – the first champion of the Games with gold in the women’s 10m air rifle. She was back in her physics class at West Virginia University last week, settling down “to normalcy and routine … I’m still kind of putting myself back together. Hopefully I’ll get to that soon.”

Spare a thought for …

South Africa’s women’s football striker Shiwe Nogwanya, taken off on a stretcher against Sweden on day minus two – 54 hours before the opening ceremony. And Britain’s Lutalo Muhammad – giving the summer’s most tearful interview after his last-second taekwondo final defeat. “I’m so distraught, so sorry for all the people who stayed up late to cheer. I let them down.”

Best observed tradition

Fact: every international sports event needs a flag and anthem gaffe to liven up the opening exchanges. Rio delivered both in week one – causing a diplomatic incident with China over wrongly-orientated flag stars, and playing an unidentified piece of music as the Nigeria men’s footballers stood to attention in Manaus.

TV ratings: the stars …

a) Clare Balding – hasn’t paused for breath since 5 August; b) Irish brothers Gary and Paul O’Donovan, going viral with their craic-based interview on RTE about Nutella, peeing in cups and how bad they felt about being in Rio due to missing the Rio-themed parties back in Skibbereen; c) Bradley Wiggins – taking time out after his gold medal to do his Phil Hindes impression. And d) Kiribati weightlifter David Katoatau, performing the Games’ best viral dance hit after his lifts.

… and the rest

a) Canada’s CBC apologised twice early on –once for a swimming commentator mistaking Michael Phelps for Ryan Lochte all the way through the 200m individual medley, then again when a different swimming commentator who thought he was off-air said: “The little 14-year-old from China dropped the ball, baby. Too excited, went out like stink, died like a pig”; b) US official broadcaster NBC earned its own tribute hashtag #NBCfail for a string of pundit and delayed-coverage based-complaints, and for throwing to five ad breaks in the first half hour of the opening ceremony; c) John Inverdale; and d) The otherwise top-drawer BBC graphics team, who didn’t think it through before showing a table of the most Googled athletes of the summer – which featured Oscar Pistorius at No2.

Most enduring debate

Surrounded the official, heavily focus-grouped Rio 2016 logo – a design a year in the making, which was turned into mantelpiece souvenirs for medal winners. It was, said organisers, an “inspirational” take on the “sinuous curves” of Sugarloaf Mountain. The internet preferred “rainbow jockstrap”.

Best upgrade

Four years ago Desiree Henry was one of the seven cauldron-lighters in London. On Friday she won bronze in the 4x100m.

Best gratitude

Japanese wrestler Risako Kawai – celebrating gold by body-slamming her 56-year-old coach to the mat, twice. “He asked me to lift him on my shoulders. I wanted to be first to slam him.”

Most British moment

Jason Kenny - packing his kit into his supermarket Bag For Life after winning gold. Father Michael told the Bolton News: “He’s not always had a Bag For Life. He recently upgraded from a thin, disposable Tesco bag.”

Best rewards

Honouring employees this month: a) Indian Railways rewarding 58kg freestyle wrestling bronze medallist and Northern Railways senior clerk Sakshi Malik with promotion to the rank of “gazetted officer”, amid reports of a planned “grand felicitation for Sakshi to celebrate her stupendous feat”; and b) The Philippines airforce, promoting weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz from Airwoman 2nd Class to Airwoman 1st Class. Diaz became the nation’s first medallist for 20 years.

Most uncomfortable

The Daily Mail, feeling uneasy last week with two men hugging: “Steady on chaps! Britain’s victorious synchronised divers hug for joy after winning gold – while China’s bronze medallists settle for a manly pat on the back.”

Most encouraging

Less successful divers giving the rest of us hope: Malaysia’s Ahmad Amsyar Azman pulled off a 3m springboard belly flop for 9.75 points; Russia’s Ilya Zakharov entered the water on all fours for 0 points; and fellow Russian Nadezhda Bazhina delivered a rare 3m springboard back flop, also securing 0 points.

Breakthrough media star

Chinese swimmer Fu Yuanhui earned praise back home for engaging interviews, including breaking the sporting taboo of discussing menstruation; not realising she’d won a medal until the interviewer told her; and whooping after her semi‑final victory: “Whoooaah I was so fast! I used all of my mystic energy!”

Nan of the summer

Mavis Williams, 74 – “#OlympicNan” with 7,880 followers after she tweeted her joy over grandson Adam Peaty’s 100m breaststroke gold. Peaty: “She only learned to use an iPad three weeks ago. Do you know how long it took me to reach 7,000 Twitter followers? But her? Overnight, just like that.”

Most inevitable Brexit spat

@LeaveEUOfficial tweeting a montage of Brits including silver medal cyclist Callum Skinner, with the message: “We may be small, but we truly are Great Britain!” Skinner tweeted back an EU flag emoticon, adding: “Thanks for the support, but I wish you wouldn’t use my image to promote your campaign.”

Most relaxed summer

Lifeguards at the Olympic pools – on vigilant standby to rescue any Olympic non-swimmers. 75 guards were on duty during the Games, paid a reported £260 each for the fortnight.

Best of the animals

1) Lorenzo the horse, dancing to “Smooth” by Santana in the individual dressage. 2) And the eye-catching capybaras on the golf course. US team director Andy Levinson: “They sort of look like a dog. Kind of a like a dog-pig.”

Theme of the summer

The early Tinder and Grindr tabloid tryst stories soon gave way to tales of wholesome romance. Among the accepted proposals: rugby sevens venue volunteer Marjorie Enya proposing to Brazil player Isadora Cerullo; British race walker Tom Bosworth proposing to boyfriend Harry Dineley; USA’s Will Claye proposing to girlfriend Queen Harrison; and Chinese diver Qin Kai proposing to fellow diver He Zi, just after she was awarded 3m springboard silver.

Related: Rio 2016 Olympics: Mo Farah wins again as Team GB beat 2012 medal haul – live!

Memes of the summer

Were more creative than usual, thanks to Rio events being staged with vivid green-screen style backdrops. It led to multiple online remixes of top level action – including tennis in space, and divers landing in volcanoes.

And the most put out

Japanese pole vaulter Hiroki Ogita – feeling upset by global press coverage suggesting he had knocked the bar off with his penis. “I never expected the foreign media to take me down like this. It’s untrue, and I am devastated that they go so far to make something up to mock and ridicule me so much.” He later tweeted: “Watching again, this is pretty funny, if I say so myself. LOL.”

Being tickled is not funny. I write as a person who hasn’t lifted their arms above 45 degrees in 30 years for fear of a rogue hand sneaking into my sleeve and wiggling.

A new documentary, one of the standout films at this year’s Sundance festival, confirms the dark side of tickling. New Zealand journalist David Farrier, a man who has made a career out of “looking at the weird and bizarre side of life”, noticed ads popping up in his timeline, asking: “Are you ticklish?” He followed them to a series of videos showing scenes of “competitive endurance tickling”. Young men in Adidas are restrained at the wrists and ankles, and tickled until they can’t take it any more.

When Farrier contacted Jane O’Brien Media, the company behind the videos, who advertise for young athletes to compete (if successful, they’re flown to LA and paid $1,500), he received a Facebook message. “To be brutally frank,” it wrote, “association with a homosexual journalist is not something that will [sic] embrace.” They threatened him with legal consequences should he pursue his investigation. Tickling was, they said, a “passionately and exclusively heterosexual athletic endurance activity”. So Farrier bought a plane ticket.

He followed the videos, in his attempts to find out more about Jane O’Brien Media. Their website opens with a recruitment video of the type you’d find when browsing LinkedIn for jobs in world domination and web design. Farrier went deep into the world of tickling. Side note: there is a world of tickling.

He met men who reported being doxxed – threatened with online exposure – after saying they no longer wanted to participate in competitive tickling (some having been told the tickling videos were for the military to test tickling as a torture device). They alleged that Jane O’Brien Media created websites containing their name and address, alongside videos of them tied up and breathless. Jane O’Brien Media denies this. In the film all roads lead to a single wealthy man, shielded by cash and threats of litigation – an ex-teacher called David D’Amato, a man who served time in 2001 after committing cyber crimes as retaliation against a teenager who’d ended their tickle video business relationship. D’Amato went by the name Terri Tickle.

Our most ticklish areas are also our weakest – neck, stomach – where we’re soft and honest. I looked it up. In 2013, scientists in Germany investigated tickling, looking at MRIs of a brain when a person laughs at something they find funny, and then when they’re tickled. They found that tickling activates the part of our brain that anticipates pain. When you tickle someone, you’re stimulating the same nerves that make you want to run away from danger. Which is why you can’t tickle yourself – your body knows there’s nothing at stake.

The film is one of those that ruins nice things for you. The lights go down on an audience that enjoys the intimacy of a sly tickle, that sees the laughter as pure and joyful. They leave with their balloons popped.

I am a guilty tickler. I tickle our toddler with the love that comes from the very unlikeliness of having created a whole other human, one with their own voice and armpits. But like much of my new life, full of potential allergies and heatwaves, it often releases little bubbles of concern. Am I forcing her to laugh, is the pleasure only mine? It’s no surprise that tickling has a sinister side – since we were children we’ve known the torture of being caught. But this film plays it out to a painful conclusion, meaning all innocence is lost. In the film – which the company says contains numerous inaccuracies – tickling is revealed as a means of control and sadism, despite the participants’ consent. The audience returns home, spoiled for ever. I haven’t tickled my child since.

Watching this film, with its scenes of the restrained boy being videoed, its lawsuits and its use of societal homophobia as a weapon against participants, is a disquieting and frustrating experience. The worst thing though, is that watching people cracking up, even against this background of darkness and bullying, really makes you laugh. You can’t help it. Like being tickled, perhaps, the danger bit of your brain clicks in and you hold your hand over your mouth and try to keep control. It’s agony.
